message: Row the Boat! Wishing our Bronco football team luck today as they face a tough Wisconsin team in the Cotton Bowl Classic. Here's hoping to a great finish to what has been a historic season!

As the 114th Congress officially comes to a close, we pause to take a quick look back at the last six years that I had the honor of serving as Chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Six years with the gavel. It goes by pretty fast. But a brief glimpse in the rear view mirror reveals that we left nothing on the table. Our 562 hearings produced a lot. And historically, we excelled. And even with all six years occurring with a divided government, we got the job done.   Multi-year, multi-Congress efforts paid off in the form of landmark chemical safety updates and mental health reforms. Public health was a beacon of much of our success, with dozens of laws now on the books to help all Americans, including the capstone legislation to deliver #CuresNow.   Because of the work and dedication of all of our members, we defied the wisdom that Washington was broken and passed 354 bills and provisions through the House with 202 bills and provisions being signed into law. Pretty impressive for a Congress that's not supposed to function. We had big ideas. And through hard work and determination, we had big results.

Today it was announced that I have been selected to lead the Subcommittee on Energy, a powerful panel with jurisdiction over national energy policy, in the 115th Congress!   Here in Michigan weâ€™ve become a national leader in promoting 21st century energy policies, having just enacted long-term, bipartisan energy legislation. We must work to do the same at the federal level. Energy solutions have long been a priority of mine and we must continue to promote â€œall-of-the-aboveâ€ strategies. Whether it be assuring families have access to affordable energy, updating standards and safety for pipelines, providing appropriate security for our electric grid, developing safer technologies for emerging energy productions, or using energy as part of our diplomatic arsenal.   Americaâ€™s energy future is bright and Iâ€™m excited to get to work. Learn more below:
Pleasure to be at Lake Michigan College for the FIRST Robotics kickoff event! Cannot wait to see what our local students come up with this year.

In observance of National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day we are displaying these blue lights in my office window. To the thousands of men and women law enforcements officers across the country we say thank you for the difficult work you do to keep our nation safe every single day. #lawenforcementappreciationday

Was honored to receive recognition from the Bipartisan Policy Center for our work on the 21st Century Cures Act. It was a true bipartisan victory for patients, families, and job-creators not only here in Southwest Michigan but across the country!

Ibrahim is a model immigrant and should be allowed to stay here in America where he has raised a family, runs a successful small business, and has become part of the fabric of our community. Our work continues...

Today is a day that embraces the very best we can offer as members of our community. The opportunity to serve others in meaningful ways, to bond and open dialogue with folks we might not otherwise interact with, and to celebrate the enduring legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. A legacy of bringing people closer together.   To that end, I was grateful to take part in several important community events. One was the Lake Michigan College MLK breakfast where we had a record turnout. And another was the Kalamazoo Ecumenical Senior Center's 23rd annual MLK birthday celebration. #MLKDAY
Always great to be with fellow Rotarians here in Kalamazoo. Gave a brief update on the 21st Century Cures Act (now law!) and the priorities of the new Congress. Great dialogue and great questions.
Great day in Kalamazoo!

These are four common-sense, bipartisan bills that will encourage job creation, increase accountability, and improve safety and affordability for consumers. As the new Congress gets underway, we will continue to advance solutions that ensure affordable energy for all American families.
You don't look a day over 170...Happy 180th Birthday to our great state of Michigan!

It was an honor to be recognized this week at the â€œFrontier of Mental Health and Addictionâ€ reception with Patrick Kennedy and U.S. Rep. Joe Kennedy, D-Massachusetts. Mental health is an issue that impacts every community, and so many families, in one way or another. For far too long, mental health was a subject left in the shadows. Thankfully, it has emerged into the light and issues are better understood.  As part of the landmark 21st Century Cures Act, we advanced the most significant reforms to our nationâ€™s mental health programs in decades. Our work will make a real difference and help families in mental health crisis here in Michigan and across the country.   This is an issue that deserves a strong voice and bipartisan support. We will continue to fight for common-sense policies that stress treatment not tragedy.

I fully support strengthening our screening processes and securing our borders, but this Executive Order needs to be scaled back. It has created real confusion for travelers and those who enforce the laws. I have heard from a number of local folks with valid concerns for themselves or loved ones as well from global companies that have legitimate worries relating to the international travel of their employees. A wiser course would have been to work with Congress to ensure that all visitors to our nation are properly vetted with appropriate documentation. Moving forward, I will continue to advocate for common-sense, bipartisan policies that protect America but also stay true to our values.

Tomorrow morning the subcommittee on energy will hold it's first hearing of 2017 focused on what the electricity sector is currently doing to prepare and respond to cybersecurity threats. Here in Michigan and across the country, electricity enables telecommunications, financial transactions, the transport and delivery of energy, food.  It powers the infrastructure that delivers our drinking water. It enables business and industry to make and provide the goods and services of our modern society.  It powers our hospitals, our households. So cyber threats to reliability deserve our constant examination, especially as new risks rapidly emerge. I have no doubt that he will serve our country with distinction and uphold our Constitution. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly confirm him as they did unanimously before.

Growing up on the shores of Lake Michigan instilled in me a deep appreciation for our Great Lakes. I have always worked in a responsible, bipartisan manner to improve the health and beauty of these precious natural resources. I appreciate the new administrationâ€™s willingness to engage on these important issues and look forward to working with them to promote, strengthen, and preserve our Great Lakes.

Also had the chance to swing by SJHS here in St. Joseph. The robotics team was in there working hard on their robot. Great to see the next generation of innovators right here at home.

One year ago, a madman attempted to rip our community apart. These inexplicable actions reverberated across the country and brought to our corner of the state a level of pain we have never experienced before. But now, we stand together stronger than ever against hatred and violence.  Today we remember the six victims snatched from our world far too soon: Mary Jo Nye, a well-respected English teacher; Barbara Hawthorne, a former Kelloggâ€™s employee; Dorothy Brown, known in her neighborhood for her herb garden; Mary Lou Nye, a preschool and early childcare advocate; Tyler Smith, a well-liked student at Mattawan High School; and Richard Smith, a construction manager and loving father and husband.  We also keep in our hearts and minds the two fearless survivors. Abigail Kopf, whose courage in the face of unimaginable pain serves as a daily reminder of bravery and hope, and Tiana Carruthers who selflessly put herself in harmâ€™s way without thinking twice. We again thank our law enforcement and first responders who prevented this tragedy from being even worse.  The pain of the past never fully recedes, but when we look to the horizon â€“ to a bright new day â€“ we are able to find hope and renewed spirit amongst our friends, neighbors, and fellow community members. On this day of solemn remembrance, we do not turn to the right nor to the left, but instead we turn from evil.

I said on the House Floor last year that this tragedy would not define, divide, nor defeat us. Inspiring to be part of such a strong community as last night we honored those lives lost in Kalamazoo one-year ago.  Together, we move forward.

Wonderful panel discussion at the Western Michigan University Homer Stryker M.D. School of Medicine Every single American has been touched in some fashion by disease â€“ with 21st Century Cures we are delivering hope to patients and families across the country. This landmark legislation included $1.5 billion for the BRAIN Initiative to improve our understanding of diseases like Alzheimerâ€™s, and speed diagnoses and treatment of brain injuries. Whether it be mental health, brain disorders, PTSD, or opioid addiction, we must look to the future and work together to tackle these problems.
Incredible visit and great learning experience with folks over at the Bethany Christian Services Refugee Center in GR.

President Trumpâ€™s address tonight was a focused, optimistic vision for the future of our country. He offered common ground on goals we can all agree on such as creating American jobs, making needed investments in our infrastructure, delivering for our veterans, and rebuilding our healthcare system. I also fully support the presidentâ€™s call to safely speed approvals for life-saving drugs and devices which is exactly what our groundbreaking 21st Century Cures Act does. As we move forward, I continue to believe we are better served by working together. My hope is that we will see more bipartisan cooperation so that we can get the job done for the American people.

These reports are alarming. We have previously communicated with the new administration that our Great Lakes must be a priority and the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative must be fully funded. Congress will have the final say on all budgetary matters and we are only at the first step in the appropriations process which actually funds the program. As we move forward, I will be fighting hard alongside colleagues on both sides of the aisle so we can turn this around and make sure our Great Lakes are properly protected.
Enjoyed a productive and informative meeting with some Southwest Michigan farmers today!

The presidentâ€™s budget proposal acknowledges our unsustainable national debt and does attempt to put us on the path to fiscal responsibility. However, I remain deeply concerned about proposed cuts to important domestic programs like the National Institutes of Health and especially to our Great Lakes. Itâ€™s penny wise but pound foolish. I will continue to work the administration, the appropriate committees, and colleagues on both sides of the aisle as we move forward in this process.

Enjoyed an interesting exchange with Dr. Shuren of the Food and Drug Administration about medical innovations and the strides weâ€™ve already made thanks to the 21st Century Cures Act. We also talked about how we can work together to ensure the medical discoveries of tomorrow â€“ and the jobs that come with them â€“ will take place right here in the United States and not overseas.

Fighting this tragic opioid epidemic is personal to families in Southwest Michigan and across the country. We need to help those caught in the web of this unforgiving addiction through improving treatment, reforming prescribing practices, and working with our law enforcement. Last Congress, we were able to usher the 21st Century Cures Act into law, which provided $1 billion for drug treatment. I look forward to engaging with the new administration, the Commission, and my colleagues on both sides of the aisle here in Congress as we continue working together to end this scourge.

I grew up in a family that fostered kids, this hits close to home. Awesome work Kih'lee!

Tonight the U.S. House of Representatives advanced two pieces of bipartisan legislation to address urgent threats posed by North Korea. In recent weeks, the Kim Jong Un regime has escalated  threats against American lives. In response to these troubling provocations, we have taken action.   Tonight's measures push the State Department to determine whether North Korea should be re-listed as a State Sponsor of Terrorism and officially condemn their development of nuclear weapons. As we move forward, we must be clear-eyed in our resolve to protect our citizens from this rogue state.

BREAKING: Congresswoman Diana DeGette and I are urging the administration to rethink proposed budget cuts to the National Institutes of Health. NIH research saves millions of lives every year making the basic discoveries that allow businesses to develop new treatments, medications, and cures for patients. This is not a partisan issue. Disease isnâ€™t Democratic or Republican.

Nice to chat with Michigan Upward Bound students including Andres Garcia from Fennville. Upward Bound provides fundamental support to participants in their preparation for college entrance. The program provides opportunities for participants to succeed in their pre-college performance and ultimately in their higher education pursuits. Upward Bound serves high school students from low-income families; and high school students from families in which neither parent holds a bachelor's degree.

After Assad delivered a heinous chemical attack on his own citizens, an unmistakable message had to be delivered. As we move forward, the administration must work with Congress and the international community to support these efforts.

Last week, I had the opportunity to speak at Dr. John Dunnâ€™s farewell celebration at Miller Auditorium on the campus of Western Michigan University. Western grew exponentially under Dr. Dunnâ€™s tenure. The Western Michigan University Homer Stryker M.D. School of Medicine, the new affiliation with the Thomas M. Cooley Law School, and the renovation of Heritage Hall just to name a few examples.  But it was never just about bricks and mortar with Dr. Dunn. He has a servantâ€™s heart and truly cares about the students. And the students respect him back. Itâ€™s apparent in all the interactions Iâ€™ve seen. Whether itâ€™s a Bronco football game on a glorious fall day or trudging through the wind and snow to commemorate MLK day, or the many heartfelt hugs shared during graduation ceremonies.   I also want to take this opportunity to welcome Dr. Edward Montgomery to the Bronco family. This is a great fit for our entire Kalamazoo community. I congratulated Dr. Montgomery on his new role and look forward to working closely with him, just as I did with Dr. Dunn, as we make Southwest Michigan an attractive home to the leaders of the future.  More than anything: Thank you Dr. Dunn. Your hard work and dedication has helped make Western Michigan the special place it is today.   Photo credit: Mike Lanka.

It seems like everyone I meet is in some way impacted by this tragic opioid epidemic. These grants will directly help those in need here in Southwest Michigan and across the country. As part of our bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act, we fought hard to include this funding to aid in this public health crisis. Now, weâ€™re delivering. Awesome visit with the CW Tech Robotarians at Eagle Technology! Theyâ€™ve worked so hard on their robotics but more importantly their service project that promotes awareness of a visual condition called Convergence Insufficiency (CI) which affects only 8 percent of the population. Their mission is to educate folks and advocate for a simple 30 second diagnostic to be included in early elementary vision testing. Great kids doing great work for our community!
April was a busy month out here in D.C. but more importantly back home! Hereâ€™s a few pictures recapping some of the events I was able to participate in.

Today I voted to advance the American Health Care Act. Here's why:   Obamacare is broken. One out of three counties across the country have only one insurance provider and it looks like it will only get worse as others are on the verge of pulling the plug. Nearly two dozen of the non-profit co-ops have gone belly up. Here in Michigan folks saw their premiums increased by nearly 17 percent. Some forecast a 40-to-50 percent rate increase if nothing happens.  High premiums, lack of access, rising costs. These donâ€™t just impact Republicans or Democrats. They impact us all. The status quo is simply unacceptable.  Our legislation is a first step in the right direction to ensure all Americans have access to quality, affordable healthcare. We expand and enhance Health Savings Accounts. We provide a reasonable transition until 2020 for those on the Medicaid expansion and then grandfather all those folks until theyâ€™re off. We help young adults stay on their parents insurance until theyâ€™re 26. We provide a monthly tax credit for low and middle-income individuals and families who donâ€™t receive insurance through work or government program.  We also protect those with pre-existing conditions. I told the president directly this week that I would not support this bill as written without a fix. He took the challenge and we walked him through the problems and potential solutions. Covering those with pre-existing conditions is of the utmost importance to me. Our bill already ensures that insurance companies are prohibited from denying coverage based on pre-existing conditions. Our amendment further protects people from the financial impact associated with having a pre-existing condition.  I also voted in favor of H.R. 2192, which makes a simple technical correction to H.R. 1628 to ensure that the AHCA and its amendments apply equally to everyone. If the AHCA becomes law, members of Congress and congressional staff will be treated the same as any other citizen as it should be.   No, this process has not been perfect. I have heard from many on both sides of this debate. I pledge to continue listening and will be a constructive partner in making our healthcare system work better for all Americans.

I have always advocated for an independent and non-political FBI. "Just the facts, please." I am not privy to the justification nor the details behind the firing but the replacement must restore the public confidence immediately. It cannot be a partisan selection. As it relates the Russian investigation, I remain hopeful that the existing bipartisan Congressional committees in the House and Senate can find answers for the many questions. If need be, I would support a special prosecutor at the appropriate time. We must continue to follow the facts wherever they lead.
Jobs, jobs, jobs! Honored to participate in the official groundbreaking for the $52-million Exchange Building project beginning in Kalamazoo.

We must continue to follow the facts wherever they lead so that we can get to the bottom of this.
As #PoliceWeek starts to wrap up, I want to thank our men and women in uniform, and their families, for their service and dedication to our communities and country.

This is tragic news that breaks the heart of every parent out there. The scenes we saw on television this morning were shocking but we never thought it could be one of our own fellow Michiganders. It brings this grief so close to home. As a community we should keep her family, her classmates, and her sister, who is still recovering, close to our hearts.
Had a great time Saturday at the "Punjabi Mela" in celebration of Vaisakhi hosted by the Punjabi Cultural Society at the Wings Event Center here in Kalamazoo!

As Iâ€™ve said before, the presidentâ€™s budget proposal is just that: A proposal. Many of the proposed cuts to important domestic programs that many Michiganders rely on are, frankly, non-starters. Of particular concern is funding for our Great Lakes and the National Institutes of Health. This process is only beginning. I will continue to advocate for common-sense budgeting that reels in spending, makes government more accountable, but also properly funds essential programs the most vulnerable amongst us depend on.

Got to meet with students from the Comstock STEM Academy after they traveled out to Washington, DC to get a firsthand look at civics in action. I always appreciate the opportunity to chat with students. We are fostering the next generation of innovators right here in SW Michigan. Best of luck to these sharp students!
Join me in paying our solemn respects to the many generations of heroes who sacrificed their tomorrows so that we may enjoy our freedoms today. We are truly the land of the free because of our brave.

Great news --> St. Joseph Harbor is essential for local jobs and economic activity both here in Southwest Michigan and throughout our state. Dredging ensures our harbors remain properly maintained and benefits commercial shipping, recreational boating, and JOBS.

Discussed the need enact pro-growth tax reforms, make critical upgrades to our infrastructure, create Michigan jobs, and took Q&A today at the West Coast Chamber Luncheon in Holland. #MI06

When it comes to mental health issues, it's about treatment not tragedy. That was the message during the ribbon cutting ceremony for the new Psych Crisis Center in the Borgess Emergency Room here in Kalamazoo. Proud to be a part of such a special event.   Photo credit: Lew Tysman

Today I had the opportunity to meet with members of the Pfizer leadership team and CEO Ian Read to discuss their continued multi-million dollar manufacturing plant expansion in Portage. According to a recent economic impact study, the investment along with ongoing site operations brings in more than $2 billion in economic activity annually and 5,680 jobs to the region.   This is truly a great community partnership. I want to commend Pfizerâ€™s leadership for expanding their base right here in Portage. This multi-million dollar investment here at home will mean more good-paying local jobs and improved quality of life for patients across the country.   We also discussed the critical need for bipartisan tax reform to keep this positive growth and job creation going. I was glad to join the leadership team today to learn about the expansion and what we can do at the federal level to continue bringing in these jobs and putting our local manufacturers on a level playing field with the rest of the world.
I want to applaud the Detroit Tigers organization for their solemn recognition of Ron Kienzle, Joseph Zangaro, and other fallen Michigan officers.

#VIDEO: Yesterday, the Energy and Commerce Committee voted to advance the FDA Reauthorization Act of 2017, by a 54 to 0 vote. Here in Southwest Michigan we have thousands of jobs that are affected by this legislation â€“ whether on the device side at Stryker, the generics side at Perrigo, the manufacturing side at Pfizer, or the dozens of smaller biotech and manufacturing firms in our communities.   Passing this legislation is vital to these good-paying, local jobs as well as to patients who will benefit from the new therapies it helps get to market.   Without swift enactment, the FDA will be forced next month to start laying off up to 70 percent of their employees that approve drugs and devices. Now that our groundbreaking, bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act is law, reauthorizing these FDA user-fee programs is an important next step to ensuring these jobs stay here in Michigan and patients across the country benefit from improved, life-saving therapies.
This is about Michigan jobs and our economy -->

#BREAKING - Tonight the U.S. House of Representatives voted to advance ten bipartisan energy construction, infrastructure, and efficiency bills.These ten common-sense bills put job creators first and will boost our economy here in Michigan and across the country. They will also lower costs for ratepayers, reduce emissions, and allow for more domestic energy production.   Here in the House we will continue to advance an â€˜all-of-the-aboveâ€™ energy strategy that puts a premium on creating jobs and lifting our economy. I applaud my colleagues from both sides of the aisle for their work in passing this legislation with such overwhelmingly bipartisan support.

I am OK. My heart is going out to my friend Steve Scalise, his family, & all my colleagues, staff, & brave law enforcement who were injured in the shooting this morning.

It was a tough week at the Capitol after the events of Wednesdayâ€™s shooting at the congressional baseball practice.  I want to personally thank everyone who reached out to check on me and my staff this week. It meant the world to us. The heat surrounding politics right now is at an all-time high. We can disagree on policy â€“ thatâ€™s what makes our country great â€“ but Iâ€™ve always been one who tries to find common ground. I spend my time trying to do the right thing for folks in Southwest Michigan. We can have our differences but letâ€™s not let it lead to such hate.    To that end, our office was open and operational this week and it was great to discuss the issues with many folks in town from back home.
Spent the day working across Southwest Michigan - great to see so many of you!

Today our community says goodbye to Comstock Fire Chief Ed Switalski. Chief Switalski was a long-time firefighter who will be remembered for his dedication. Join me in sending heartfelt condolences to his friends and family during this difficult time. We are forever grateful for his service.

In the face of ever-evolving physical and cyber threats, today my colleagues and I took a big step towards modernizing our nationâ€™s energy security and infrastructure. Elevating energy security planning and emergency preparedness is important and timely. Whether itâ€™s a storm that knocks out power to millions of homes and businesses or attempted hacking of our energy grid â€“ we must be prepared. Asian Carp have the potential to decimate the Great Lakes we all love and depend on. The time to act is now.   It is absolutely imperative we step up our efforts to further protect our lakes. I will continue to work with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle here in the House and the Senate to take action to stop Asian Carp from entering our waterways.  I am also calling on the Trump administration to immediately release the Brandon Road Study so that we can have a full grasp of our options to stop this destructive force.

In addition to the positive steps Michigan is taking, the House of Representatives passed legislation last week that would improve career and technical education opportunities and reauthorize the Carl D. Perkins Act. This will directly help students develop the skills they need to compete for high-skilled, in-demand jobs. Local career and technical education, or CTE, programs help prepare high school and community college students with the knowledge and hands-on experience necessary to succeed in careers in a broad range of industries. In order to support and grow our middle class, we need to support and grow CTE programs that help countless students succeed. Thatâ€™s exactly what our bipartisan legislation does and I was proud to support its passage.

Excited to move forward with these bipartisan bills so that Michigan can continue leading the way in developing, testing and deploying the cars and trucks of the future.

One-year ago today, our community was shaken by a violent and heinous act that took the lives of two dedicated public servants and threatened the lives of those inside the Berrien County Courthouse. Since that day we have come together in a healing process and seen an outpouring of support for Sheriff Paul Bailey, his department, and all of our local law enforcement and first responders.  Today is a solemn reminder of what we went through and we mark it by remembering Joseph Zangaro, whom I knew personally. He was a widely respected and well-liked former Michigan State Police Trooper and head of courthouse security. We also remember Ronald Kienzle, a U.S. Army veteran and retired Benton Township Police Officer who loved his motorcycle and his family.  What happened right here in our community is a daily reminder of the sacrifices our law enforcement officers, and their families, make every single day in order to keep the rest of us safe and secure. This heartbreaking tragedy happened in the blink of an eye, but we will never forget.  Thanks to ABC 57 for telling this story. Click below to watch my interview with them:

You may not have seen this on the news...but here in the U.S. House we just advanced a critical piece of bipartisan legislation that is about two things: improving public health and jobs.   Now that our groundbreaking 21st Century Cures Act is law, we need to make sure that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is able to handle new breakthrough treatments in a timely and predictable fashion. All while maintaining the highest levels of safety. Thatâ€™s why these user fee agreements are so important. Theyâ€™re also important to our economy right here in Southwest Michigan where we have literally thousands of jobs that are affected by this legislation.   I was proud to champion this bipartisan legislation that is vital to these good-paying, local jobs as well as patients who will benefit from new therapies it helps get to market. Happy 104th Birthday to former President, fellow Wolverine, and Michigan legend Gerald Ford!  Youâ€™re a role model who was never afraid to work across the aisle to tackle the challenges facing our nation. Your legacy speaks for us all here in Michigan who know the importance of working together and your statue - enshrined in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda - serves as a daily reminder to work in your fashion.

Last week the U.S. House of Representatives advanced the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018 by a bipartisan 344 to 81 vote. This is a critical step forward towards strengthening our military, keeping our country safe, standing up for our men and women in uniform, and their families, all while protecting taxpayer dollars. I was proud to sponsor legislation alongside Senators Stabenow and Peters to make then-Private First Class McCloughan eligible for our nationâ€™s highest military honor. What is happening in #Charlottesville is most disturbing. It shames us as a nation. It needs to stop. Now. We are all watching. It threatens the very core of our country: Tolerance, acceptance, & embracing diversity. We must join together to oppose this divisiveness.

Let me be clear: There are no 'very fine' white supremacists. I join with many others in denouncing this sort of unacceptable racism and bigotry and condemning white supremacy, neo-Nazi, and KKK groups - particularly the ones whose actions led to tragic violence in Charlottesville.    My father fought in the Battle of the Bulge during World War II against the Nazi's. That kind of evil and hatred must be stamped out.  I have always been one who looks to bring folks together. Iâ€™ll continue to speak out against racism, divisive rhetoric, and violence just as I did on Saturday.

The Forever GI bill, now LAW, is a transformational expansion of GI Bill benefits granted to veterans, their surviving spouses, and dependents. Since 1944 the GI Bill has provided our veterans the opportunity to invest in their futures through access to education benefits. By growing these education and workforce training opportunities we can help ease their transition from active duty to civilian life.

#BREAKING - H.R. 2430, the FDA Reauthorization Act of 2017 is now LAW.  Workers, job creators, and patients here in Michigan and across the country depend on this legislation, and we just delivered.   This bipartisan legislation is about two things: Local jobs and improving public health.   As Iâ€™ve visited with local workers and leaders of innovative companies like Pfizer, which recently announced a multi-million dollar expansion in Portage, theyâ€™ve told me first-hand how important this legislation is to protect these good-paying, local jobs. Iâ€™ve also heard from patients who have benefitted from the new therapies the FDA helps get to market thanks to this legislation. Itâ€™s a win-win.   This action is so important to Southwest Michigan and Iâ€™m pleased to see it signed into law today.

Today I voted down an Amendment that would have cut the EPA by nearly 25 percent. The passage of this amendment would have meant cuts to the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GRLI). Thatâ€™s a non-starter for me. The GLRI is vital to the health of our Great Lakes: It helps us fight Asian Carp and other invasive species, invests in Michigan jobs, our drinking water, and way of life.   I have consistently stood up against misguided efforts to undermine this program and will continue to do so. The amendment was bad news from the start and Iâ€™m very pleased that Republicans and Democrats came together to defeat it.

In the wake of the horrific tragedy in Las Vegas itâ€™s clear that we cannot with a straight face justify the legality of bump stocks - tools that can so easily be manipulated to do unimaginable harm and are specifically designed to get around the automatic weapon ban. There is no place for them in a civil society. None.  I am currently working with other members of Congress who share my concerns on a letter to the ATF. It is my hope that after a thorough examination, the ATF will agree with us and conclude these mechanisms violate the law and will be banned.  It is our responsibility to look at what happened in Las Vegas and find ways to take action. This is a step we can and should take. Iâ€™m proud to stand up and push this common-sense effort to ban bump stocks.

#VIDEO: Spoke today during the House Committee on Energy and Commerce Member Day about need to address the opioid addiction & abuse crisis.   This silent epidemic has torn through families, neighborhoods, and communities both in my home state of Michigan and indeed across the entire country. In 2015, there were nearly 2,000 opioid abuse related deaths in Michigan alone. Even more tragically, more than 22,000 babies are born every year across the country with Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome.  It has hit home both in my community and yes, even my own family. This is personal to me.  In the last few years I have been meeting with first responders, crisis center employees, advocacy groups, and yes â€“ individuals suffering. All of these folks have said that, tragically, the death toll continues to rise.  This is why we have been taking concrete action here in the Energy and Commerce Committee to combat this widespread epidemic. Just last year, the president signed into law a sweeping package aimed at attacking the opioid epidemic from all sides.  As part of my landmark, bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act, an additional 1 billion dollars was allocated to states, like Michigan, to address opioid addiction treatment and prevention. Just this year, the first round of that funding was delivered.  Michigan received more than 16 million dollars. This grant funding will make a real difference. To those suffering, I just say this: Help is on the way.  There is more work to be done. Clearly. And here in Congress we will continue to take steps to address this epidemic. In this committee, weâ€™re on the front lines in advancing meaningful, bipartisan legislation that will make a difference. Together, we can take this â€œsilent epidemicâ€ and bring it out of the shadows.

Today I voted for this bipartisan aid package that totals $36.5 billion for urgent, short-term needs related to recovery from Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, and wildfires in the U.S. The package passed with wide, bipartisan support 353 to 69. Today we're remembering Bugsy who passed away yesterday after a short but very well lived life.  Bugsy was an ever-enthusiastic member of our team for nearly 7 years. He loved greeting all visitors, especially children. He relished swimming in Lake Michigan in the summer, and rolling in the snow in the winter. We will miss his spirit & smile.

#BREAKING - Today I attended the bipartisan White House announcement that the Trump Administration would declare a Nationwide Public Health Emergency to address the opioid crisis.  I want to applaud the Trump Administration for taking decisive action to address the threat the opioid crisis poses. This fight is personal to me: It has hit home even in my own extended family. It has torn through families, neighborhoods, and communities both in my home state of Michigan and indeed across the entire country.  In the last few years I have been meeting with first responders, crisis center employees, advocacy groups, and yes â€“ individuals suffering. All of these folks have said that, tragically, the death toll continues to rise. As part of my landmark, bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act, an additional $1 billion was allocated to states, like Michigan, to address opioid addiction treatment and prevention. Just this year, the first round of that funding was delivered. Michigan received more than $16 million dollars. This grant funding will make a real difference. To those suffering, I just say this: Help is on the way.  But there is more work to be done. Clearly. And here in Congress we will continue to take steps to address this epidemic. We should all work together to advance meaningful, bipartisan legislation that will make a difference. Together, we can take on this â€˜silent epidemicâ€™ and bring it out of the shadows.

We have all heard countless stories from folks in Michigan impacted by a tax code that is outdated, unwieldy, and too often rewards those at the top at the cost of regular folksâ€¦it has become abundantly clear that the status quo is a major drag on our economy and on Michigan families struggling to get by.  The time for tax reform is NOW.  Our plan more than doubles the standard deduction and expands the Child Tax Credit. Both of these ideas have enjoyed bipartisan support in the past and will unquestionably help Michigan middle-class families.   Our plan also makes it easier for entrepreneurs and small business owners to realize the American dream, grow their business, and hire more workers. Growing our local economy.   Thatâ€™s what we are committed to doing.  Rep Tim Walberg, Rep. Bill Huizenga, Rep. John Moolenaar, Congressman Dave Trott, Rep. Paul Mitchell, Rep. Mike Bishop

TAX CUTS -> With this vote, historic tax reform is one step closer to reality. Hereâ€™s what our plan does for individuals:  -significantly increases the standard deduction -expands the Child Tax Credit -preserves the Adoption Tax Credit -preserves the mortgage interest deduction -expands the medical expense deduction -continues the charitable contribution deduction, and more.   We lower the corporate tax rate to 21 percent â€“ down from the highest rate in the industrialized world and eliminate incentives to move Michigan jobs overseas. We also deliver significant tax relief to Southwest Michigan small businesses.   At the end of the day this will be a big win for Michigan middle class families and our economy. After 31 years, itâ€™s time to get this done.  Local economic organizations support this tax reform opportunity as do national organizations such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Business Roundtable, National Association of Manufacturers, National Federation of Independent Business, National Association of Home Builders, and more.

ICYMI -> Our new "Year in Review and Look Ahead" report outlines several WINS for our Southwest Michigan community this year. Some of those wins: ensuring funding for St. Joseph Harbor dredging, requesting assistance from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to deal with severe erosion in New Buffalo, moving forward on the Allied Paper/Kalamazoo River Superfund cleanup, making progress in stopping the erosion of the St. Joseph bluff, keeping Palisades Nuclear Power Plant open and operational until 2022, reintroducing legislation for the benefit of our friend Ibrahim Parlak, taking part in 493 in-person meetings with constituents to hear directly from YOU and much more.  You can read the full report here: https://upton.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398939
